cities.name: San Francisco
cities.summary: San Francisco is beautiful but has highly visible urban challenges. Property crime (car break-ins, theft) is the highest in any major US city. The Tenderloin and parts of SOMA have open drug use and homelessness. But tourist areas like Fisherman's Wharf, the Marina, and Pacific Heights are safe. The city is compact and walkable in the right neighborhoods.
cities.quickVerdict: SF is safe in tourist neighborhoods but has the worst car break-in problem in America. Never leave anything in your car — ever. The Tenderloin is rough even during the day. Fisherman's Wharf, North Beach, the Marina, and Pacific Heights are all safe. The city is gorgeous and worth visiting with awareness.

neighborhoods.name: Fisherman's Wharf / North Beach
neighborhoods.description: Tourist hub — Pier 39, Ghirardelli Square, Italian restaurants. Safe and well-patrolled. Touristy and overpriced but safe. North Beach (Little Italy) is more authentic and equally safe.

neighborhoods.name: Marina / Pacific Heights
neighborhoods.description: Upscale, safe neighborhoods with beautiful views. Great restaurants and shopping on Chestnut and Fillmore streets. Palace of Fine Arts is here. Very comfortable area.

neighborhoods.name: Castro / Noe Valley
neighborhoods.description: The Castro is the historic LGBTQ+ neighborhood. Safe, vibrant, and walkable. Noe Valley is family-friendly and charming. Both are safe day and night on main streets.

neighborhoods.name: Mission District
neighborhoods.description: Incredible food, murals, and culture. Valencia Street is trendy and safe. Mission Street is grittier. Safe during the day but some blocks have drug activity. Taquerias here are the best in the city.

neighborhoods.name: SoMa
neighborhoods.description: South of Market — tech offices, museums (SFMOMA), and nightlife. Varies block by block. Some areas are fine, others have visible homelessness and drug use. Stick to the main streets.

neighborhoods.name: Tenderloin
neighborhoods.description: Open drug use, dealers, and homelessness. It's between Union Square and City Hall — easy to accidentally walk into. Not dangerous in terms of violence toward tourists, but deeply uncomfortable and property crime is rampant.

scams.name: Car Break-ins
scams.description: San Francisco has the worst car break-in rate in the US. Thieves check every parked car for visible items — bags, jackets, cables, anything. Popular tourist parking lots (Fisherman's Wharf, Golden Gate overlooks) are prime targets.
scams.howToAvoid: Leave NOTHING in your car — not even an empty bag or jacket. Remove everything including charging cables. Use the trunk before arriving. Better yet, don't rent a car at all.

scams.name: Phone / Laptop Snatching
scams.description: Thieves on bikes or on foot grab phones and laptops from café tables and distracted pedestrians. BART trains are another hotspot.
scams.howToAvoid: Don't leave devices on café tables. Be aware of your surroundings when using your phone. On BART, keep devices in your bag, not on your lap near the door.

scams.name: Fake Parking Tickets
scams.description: Fake tickets placed on windshields with QR codes leading to scam payment sites.
scams.howToAvoid: Only pay parking tickets through the official SFMTA website. Verify any ticket at sfmta.com.

scams.name: Alcatraz Ticket Resellers
scams.description: Third-party sellers charge 2-3x face value for Alcatraz tickets that are 'sold out.' Some sell combo tours with unwanted extras.
scams.howToAvoid: Book directly through alcatrazcruises.com well in advance. Tickets sell out weeks ahead. Don't buy from street sellers or unmarked kiosks.

soloFemale.overview: San Francisco is comfortable for solo women in the right neighborhoods. The city is progressive, welcoming, and compact. Avoid the Tenderloin and be cautious in SoMa at night. The public transit is good enough to get around without a car.
tips: The Marina, Pacific Heights, and North Beach are the most comfortable bases
The Tenderloin is uncomfortable even during the day — route around it
BART and Muni are safe during the day; use Uber/Lyft at night
SF's café culture is excellent for solo travelers
Golden Gate Park is great during the day — stick to main paths
The Mission's Valencia Street is a fantastic solo exploration area during daytime and early evening

nightSafety.overview: North Beach, the Marina, and the Castro are safe and lively at night. The Mission's Valencia Street has good nightlife. SoMa has clubs but the surrounding streets can feel uncomfortable. The Tenderloin is always best avoided.
tips: North Beach and the Marina are the safest evening areas
The Castro has great bars and is safe at night
Avoid the Tenderloin after dark — it borders Union Square, so know your route
SoMa nightclub areas are fine but Uber door-to-door
Don't walk through Golden Gate Park after dark

transport.metro: Muni (bus, light rail, cable cars) covers the city well. BART connects to the airport and East Bay. Both are safe during the day. Cable cars are a tourist must-do but expect long lines. Get a Clipper card for all transit.
transport.rideshare: Uber and Lyft were born here and are everywhere. Best option for late nights and hilly areas.
transport.taxis: Less common than ride-hailing. Available by app (Flywheel) or at hotel stands.
transport.tips: Don't rent a car for the city itself — parking is expensive and break-ins are rampant. Use Muni, BART, and Uber. Rent a car only for day trips (Napa, Muir Woods, Big Sur).

customs: San Francisco is progressive and welcoming to everyone — diversity is celebrated
Tech culture is everywhere — don't be surprised by conversations about startups and venture capital
Tipping: 18-20% at restaurants, standard US tipping
Dress in layers — SF's microclimate means fog and cold mornings even in summer. Mark Twain's alleged quote about SF winters rings true
Bring a jacket to the Golden Gate Bridge — it's always windy and cold there
The city is very environmentally conscious — many places don't offer plastic bags or straws

health.overview: Excellent healthcare. UCSF Medical Center is world-renowned. Standard US healthcare costs. Travel insurance recommended for international visitors.
health.water: Tap water is safe and excellent — sourced from Hetch Hetchy reservoir in Yosemite.
health.altitude: No altitude concerns. Earthquake risk is real — SF sits on the San Andreas Fault. Hotels have earthquake procedures posted.

faq.q: Is San Francisco safe for tourists?
faq.a: Yes, in tourist areas. Fisherman's Wharf, North Beach, the Marina, and Pacific Heights are safe. Property crime is high everywhere — the #1 rule is never leave anything in your car.

It has open drug use and property crime but violent attacks on tourists are rare. It's more uncomfortable than dangerous. The issue is it borders Union Square, so you can wander in accidentally. Know the boundaries.

faq.q: Do I need a car in San Francisco?
faq.a: No, and you shouldn't rent one unless leaving the city. Car break-ins are epidemic, parking is expensive, and Muni/BART/Uber cover everything in the city.

faq.q: Is it really cold in San Francisco in summer?
faq.a: Yes — summer highs average 18-20°C (64-68°F) with fog. September and October are actually the warmest months. Always bring layers.
Minor tremors happen but rarely cause damage. Know the drop-cover-hold procedure. Major earthquakes are rare but possible — check your hotel's safety information.

cities.name: Las Vegas
cities.summary: The Las Vegas Strip is one of the most heavily surveilled and policed stretches in America — casinos invest billions in security. The main risk is to your wallet (gambling, overpriced drinks, shows, and clubs) rather than your physical safety. Off-Strip areas are a different story, and the desert heat is a real health hazard.
cities.quickVerdict: The Strip and Downtown (Fremont Street) are safe for tourists. Casinos have world-class security. Your biggest risks are dehydration in the desert heat, drinking too much, and spending too much money. Off-Strip neighborhoods to the west and north can be rough. Stay on the Strip or in resort areas and you'll be fine.

neighborhoods.name: The Strip
neighborhoods.description: The 4-mile casino corridor. Incredibly well-policed and surveilled. Safe to walk day and night. Pickpockets work the crowds. The Strip is long — walking between casinos takes longer than you think.

neighborhoods.name: Downtown / Fremont Street
neighborhoods.description: The older casino district with the Fremont Experience. Less glamorous than the Strip but fun. Safe on Fremont Street itself. Surrounding blocks get rough quickly — don't wander far.

neighborhoods.name: Summerlin
neighborhoods.description: Upscale suburb west of the Strip. Red Rock Canyon nearby. Very safe, mostly residential. Good restaurants. Requires a car to access.

neighborhoods.name: Henderson
neighborhoods.description: Safe suburban area south of the Strip. Good dining and access to Lake Mead and Hoover Dam. Family-friendly alternative to Strip hotels.

neighborhoods.name: Arts District
neighborhoods.description: Growing area south of Fremont with galleries and breweries. Fine during First Friday events. Surrounding streets are undeveloped and less comfortable, especially at night.

neighborhoods.name: North Las Vegas
neighborhoods.description: Higher crime rates. Not a tourist area. No reason to visit. Easy to accidentally end up here if driving off-Strip to the north.

scams.name: Nightclub Promoter Scams
scams.description: Promoters on the Strip offer free entry or drink packages at clubs. The 'free' entry may require expensive bottle service minimums. Lines are often hours long even with a promoter.
scams.howToAvoid: Research clubs and book through official casino websites or apps. Be clear about all costs before committing.

scams.name: Timeshare Presentations
scams.description: You're offered free show tickets or cheap buffet access in exchange for attending a timeshare pitch. The 90-minute presentation becomes 4 hours of high-pressure sales.
scams.howToAvoid: Nothing is free in Vegas. If you do attend, know that you can leave at any time. Say 'no' firmly and repeatedly.

scams.name: Street Performers / Card Slappers
scams.description: People hand out cards for escort services on the Strip. Some performers are aggressive about tips. Costumed characters charge for photos.
scams.howToAvoid: Don't take the cards. Don't engage with performers unless you're willing to tip. Same rules as Times Square.

scams.name: ATM Fees
scams.description: Casino ATMs charge $5-10+ per withdrawal. This isn't technically a scam but it adds up fast.
scams.howToAvoid: Withdraw cash at your bank before traveling or use ATMs at CVS/Walgreens off-Strip. Budget cash in advance.

soloFemale.overview: The Strip is safe for solo women — security is everywhere. The nightclub scene can involve aggressive male attention. Pool parties and clubs are more comfortable with friends. Solo exploration of the casinos and restaurants is perfectly fine.
tips: The Strip is safe to walk alone day and night — security cameras and police are everywhere
Nightclubs are more enjoyable with a group — solo clubbing attracts unwanted attention
Pool parties at resort hotels are fun but watch your drinks
The restaurant and show scene is excellent for solo travelers
Uber/Lyft between the Strip and Downtown — don't walk between them
Drink water constantly — the desert air dehydrates you much faster than you think

nightSafety.overview: The Strip never sleeps and is safe at all hours due to casino security. Fremont Street is safe until late. The areas between the Strip and Downtown are not safe to walk through at night.
tips: The Strip is safe 24/7 — probably the safest place to walk at 3am in America
Fremont Street is safe during the experience hours
Do NOT walk between the Strip and Downtown — take an Uber (it's a dangerous stretch)
Avoid wandering off the Strip to the east or west — neighborhoods change quickly
Watch your alcohol consumption — the free drinks in casinos are designed to impair your judgment

transport.metro: The Las Vegas Monorail runs along the east side of the Strip. Limited but useful. The Deuce bus runs the length of the Strip and to Downtown. Both are safe.
transport.rideshare: Uber and Lyft are the main transport. Pickup points at casinos are designated — follow the signs. Can surge heavily during events and late at night.
transport.taxis: Available at every casino. Metered. Some drivers take the highway for a longer, more expensive route from the airport — ask for the surface street route (Swenson/Paradise) unless you prefer the highway.
transport.tips: Walk the Strip during the day (bring water). Uber for anything off-Strip. The Deuce bus is a cheap way to travel the full Strip length.

customs: Tipping is huge in Vegas — dealers, cocktail waitresses ($1-2 per drink, even 'free' ones), valets, hotel staff
What happens in Vegas stays in Vegas — but also, casinos have more cameras than any place on earth
Drinking on the Strip is legal — you can carry open containers on the sidewalk (in plastic, not glass)
The sun is brutal — even in spring and fall. Hydrate constantly. Summer temps reach 45°C (113°F)
Buffets aren't what they used to be — Vegas has become a serious fine dining destination
Gambling: set a budget and stick to it. The house always wins in the long run

health.overview: Good hospitals available. Sunrise Hospital and UMC are the main facilities. Standard US healthcare costs. Dehydration and heat exhaustion are real risks.
health.water: Tap water is safe but tastes heavily chlorinated. Bottled water is recommended for taste. DRINK WATER CONSTANTLY.
health.altitude: Las Vegas is at 610m — no altitude concerns. Heat is the #1 health risk. Temperatures exceed 40°C (104°F) regularly in summer.

faq.q: Is Las Vegas safe for tourists?
faq.a: The Strip is one of the safest tourist areas in America thanks to massive casino security infrastructure. Stay on the Strip and Downtown Fremont area and you'll be fine.

faq.q: Is it safe to walk the Las Vegas Strip at night?
faq.a: Yes, the Strip is safe 24/7. Casino security, police, and surveillance are constant. Pickpockets work crowds but violent crime on the Strip is rare.

faq.q: Can I walk from the Strip to Downtown?
faq.a: You physically can, but don't. The area between them is not safe, especially at night. Take an Uber — it's a 10-minute ride.

faq.q: Is it safe to drink the free casino drinks?
faq.a: The drinks are safe but designed to keep you gambling. Pace yourself. Dehydration plus alcohol in desert heat is a bad combination.

faq.q: How hot does it get in Las Vegas?
faq.a: Summer temperatures regularly exceed 40°C (104°F) and can hit 45°C (113°F). Carry water everywhere. Heat exhaustion is a real danger, not just discomfort.

cities.name: New Orleans
cities.summary: New Orleans is one of America's most unique and rewarding cities, but it has higher crime rates than most tourist destinations. The French Quarter and Garden District are well-policed and busy with tourists. Outside these areas, crime increases noticeably. The city's incredible music, food, and culture are worth the extra awareness required.
cities.quickVerdict: The French Quarter and Garden District are safe with standard precautions. Bourbon Street is chaotic but physically safe due to heavy police presence. Don't wander into unfamiliar neighborhoods, especially at night. Use Uber after dark. Watch your drinks — spiking happens. The food and music alone make New Orleans worth visiting.

neighborhoods.name: French Quarter
neighborhoods.description: The heart of New Orleans. Bourbon Street, Jackson Square, and incredible restaurants. Heavy police presence keeps it safe. Can be chaotic and rowdy but physically safe on main streets. Side streets are quieter and less patrolled.

neighborhoods.name: Garden District
neighborhoods.description: Beautiful antebellum mansions and oak-lined streets. Magazine Street has great shopping and dining. Very safe during the day. Comfortable to walk at night on main streets.

neighborhoods.name: Warehouse District / CBD
neighborhoods.description: Museums, restaurants, and the convention center. Modern and safe. Good hotel base. National WWII Museum is a must-see.

neighborhoods.name: Marigny / Bywater
neighborhoods.description: Frenchmen Street has the best live music in the city — better than Bourbon Street. Artsy neighborhood. Safe on the main strips. Some edges are rougher — don't wander too far.

neighborhoods.name: Tremé
neighborhoods.description: Historic African-American neighborhood with great music venues. Adjacent to the French Quarter. Main streets are fine during the day. Less comfortable at night. Gentrifying but still has rough patches.

neighborhoods.name: Central City / 7th Ward
neighborhoods.description: Higher violent crime rates. Not tourist areas. Easy to accidentally wander into from the Garden District or Tremé. If the area starts looking unfamiliar, take an Uber back.

scams.name: Bet You I Know Where You Got Your Shoes
scams.description: A classic New Orleans scam. Someone bets they can tell you where you got your shoes. The answer is always 'on your feet, on Bourbon Street.' Then they demand payment for winning the bet.
scams.howToAvoid: If anyone starts with 'bet you I know...' just smile and say 'no thanks' and keep walking.

scams.name: Drink Spiking
scams.description: Drinks are spiked on Bourbon Street and in bars. Both men and women are targeted. Victims are then robbed or worse.
scams.howToAvoid: Never leave your drink unattended. Don't accept drinks from strangers. Be careful with the giant daiquiris — they're already dangerously strong before anyone adds anything.

scams.name: Lucky Dog / Overpriced Street Food
scams.description: Street vendors charge inflated prices, especially during events. Not really a scam, just overpricing.
scams.howToAvoid: Eat at actual restaurants — New Orleans has the best food in America. Don't buy food from random street vendors during Mardi Gras.

scams.name: Fake Jazz Funeral Tours
scams.description: Unofficial tour operators offer overpriced or misleading tours of cemeteries and neighborhoods.
scams.howToAvoid: Book tours through established companies. Free walking tours with tips are available and excellent.

soloFemale.overview: New Orleans requires more caution than some US cities for solo women. The French Quarter is busy and well-policed. Bourbon Street at night has aggressive attention. The music scene on Frenchmen Street is more comfortable for solo women than Bourbon Street.
tips: The French Quarter and Garden District are comfortable for solo exploration during the day
Frenchmen Street is better than Bourbon Street for solo women — more relaxed, better music
Watch your drink carefully — never leave it unattended, even briefly
Use Uber after dark — even for short distances
Stay on well-lit, busy streets in the French Quarter at night
The daytime food scene is outstanding for solo dining — counter seating at places like Cochon is perfect

nightSafety.overview: Bourbon Street and Frenchmen Street are lively and reasonably safe due to crowds and police. Beyond these strips, New Orleans gets much less safe at night. The transition from safe to unsafe can happen within a few blocks.
tips: Bourbon Street is chaotic but safe on the main strip due to police presence
Frenchmen Street is the best nightlife spot — great live music every night
Don't wander off the main tourist streets at night in the French Quarter
Always Uber between areas after dark
Avoid walking toward Rampart Street from the Quarter at night

transport.metro: The iconic streetcars run on St. Charles Avenue and Canal Street. Scenic and useful but slow. Safe during the day. The city bus system covers more area but is less tourist-friendly.
transport.rideshare: Uber and Lyft are essential, especially at night. Reasonable prices. Use for all nighttime transport.
transport.taxis: United Cabs is the main company. Available by phone or at hotel stands. Reliable but more expensive than ride-hailing.
transport.tips: Walk the French Quarter and Garden District during the day. Streetcar on St. Charles Avenue is a great experience. Uber for everything at night.

customs: New Orleans runs on hospitality — friendliness is a way of life here
Tipping: 18-20%, and generous tipping to street musicians is appreciated
Drinking on the street is legal — go cups (plastic to-go cups) are offered at every bar
The food is extraordinary — don't skip beignets at Café Du Monde, po'boys, gumbo, and crawfish
Jazz is sacred — if you're in a music venue, listen respectfully and don't talk loudly over performers
Mardi Gras is incredible but the city is completely different during that time — plan accordingly

health.overview: Ochsner Medical Center and Tulane Medical Center are the main hospitals. Standard US healthcare costs. Heat and humidity are intense from May through September.
health.water: Tap water is safe but tastes chlorinated. Most locals and restaurants use filtered water.
health.vaccinations: No specific vaccinations needed. Mosquitoes are a nuisance — use repellent, especially near the river.
health.altitude: No altitude concerns. Much of the city is below sea level. Flooding is a risk during heavy rain and hurricane season (June-November).

faq.q: Is New Orleans safe for tourists?
faq.a: In the French Quarter and Garden District, yes, with standard precautions. New Orleans has higher crime than most tourist cities, but the main tourist areas are well-policed. Don't wander into unfamiliar neighborhoods.
Bourbon Street is safe due to heavy police presence and crowds. It's chaotic, loud, and rowdy — but physically safe. Watch your drink carefully and keep valuables secure.

faq.q: Where should I hear live music?
faq.a: Frenchmen Street is the best for live music — better quality than Bourbon Street, more authentic, and a safer vibe. Multiple clubs within walking distance.

faq.q: Is it safe during Mardi Gras?
faq.a: Mardi Gras in the main parade areas is safe (very heavy police presence). Stick to established parade routes and tourist areas. Exercise extra caution with belongings in crowds.
During hurricane season (June-November), monitor weather. Hotels have evacuation procedures. New Orleans takes hurricane preparedness very seriously after Katrina.

cities.name: Boston
cities.summary: Boston is one of the safest major cities in the US for tourists. It's compact, walkable, and well-connected by public transit. The historic Freedom Trail, waterfront, and university neighborhoods are all safe and enjoyable. Crime exists but is mostly concentrated in neighborhoods tourists don't visit.
cities.quickVerdict: Boston is very safe for tourists. Back Bay, Beacon Hill, the North End, and the waterfront are all comfortable to walk day and night. The T (subway) is safe during operating hours. Boston is walkable, historic, and has a great food scene. One of the easiest US cities for first-time visitors.

neighborhoods.name: Back Bay / Beacon Hill
neighborhoods.description: Beautiful brownstones, Newbury Street shopping, and Boston Common. Among the safest and most picturesque neighborhoods. Safe day and night.

neighborhoods.name: North End
neighborhoods.description: Boston's Little Italy. Incredible restaurants, historic sites, and narrow charming streets. Safe and lively. A highlight of any Boston visit.

neighborhoods.name: Cambridge / Harvard Square
neighborhoods.description: Home to Harvard and MIT. Academic, diverse, great bookstores and cafés. Safe and walkable. Easy to reach via the Red Line.

neighborhoods.name: Seaport / Waterfront
neighborhoods.description: Modern, upscale waterfront area. New England Aquarium, restaurants, and harborwalk. Very safe and family-friendly.

neighborhoods.name: South End
neighborhoods.description: Trendy restaurant scene, Victorian architecture, diverse and welcoming. One of Boston's best dining neighborhoods. Safe and walkable.

neighborhoods.name: Roxbury / Dorchester
neighborhoods.description: Mixed neighborhoods with higher crime in some areas. Some pockets of gentrification with good restaurants. Not tourist destinations. Exercise caution if visiting.

scams.name: Parking Traps
scams.description: Boston parking is confusing, expensive, and aggressively enforced. Street sweeping schedules, resident-only zones, and tight spaces catch visitors.
scams.howToAvoid: Don't drive in Boston. The T and walking cover everything. If you must park, use a garage and pay the daily rate.

scams.name: Duck Tour Knockoffs
scams.description: Unofficial tour operators near Boston Common offer subpar tours at inflated prices.
scams.howToAvoid: Book Boston Duck Tours directly. The Freedom Trail can be walked for free with the NPS app.

scams.name: Harvard Tour Hustlers
scams.description: Unofficial guides outside Harvard Yard offer paid tours. Quality varies wildly.
scams.howToAvoid: Free student-led tours are available through the Harvard admissions office. Book through the official website.

scams.name: Airport Taxi Overcharging
scams.description: Some Logan Airport taxis take longer routes to inflate the fare.
scams.howToAvoid: Use Uber/Lyft from the designated pickup area, or take the Blue Line into the city — it's fast and cheap.

soloFemale.overview: Boston is excellent for solo female travelers. It's one of the safest US cities, compact, and easy to navigate. The university culture means a diverse, progressive atmosphere. Solo dining is completely normal.
tips: Boston is one of the most comfortable US cities for solo women
Back Bay, Beacon Hill, and Cambridge are particularly comfortable
The T is safe during operating hours — it closes around 12:30am
Boston Common and the Public Garden are safe during the day
The North End is perfect for solo dining — sit at the bar for the full experience
Walking the Freedom Trail is a great solo activity — self-guided with the NPS app

nightSafety.overview: Boston's tourist areas are safe at night. Back Bay, the North End, and the Seaport are well-lit and comfortable. The T closes around 12:30am, which limits late-night transit options. Uber fills the gap.
tips: Back Bay, North End, and Seaport are safe for evening walks
The T closes around 12:30am — plan for Uber/Lyft after that
Boston Common is less comfortable after dark — walk around it, not through it
Faneuil Hall area has nightlife and is safe
Boston is relatively quiet compared to NYC — nightlife wraps up earlier

transport.metro: The T (MBTA) has 4 subway lines and covers all tourist areas. Clean and safe. Closes around 12:30am. Charlie Card gives you discounted fares. The Green Line is above-ground in places and scenic.
transport.rideshare: Uber and Lyft are widely available. Use for late nights when the T closes.
transport.taxis: Available but ride-hailing has largely replaced them. Airport taxis are flat-rate to certain zones.
transport.tips: Boston is one of the most walkable cities in America. You can cover most tourist sites on foot. The T for longer distances. Don't drive — the streets are confusing and parking is expensive.

customs: Bostonians are proud of their city and sports teams — don't insult the Red Sox, Celtics, or Patriots
Tipping: 18-20%, standard US tipping. Don't forget to tip at the many excellent seafood restaurants
Boston drivers are notoriously aggressive — be careful crossing streets even with the walk signal
The accent is real — 'pahk the cah in Hahvahd Yahd' — but don't mock it
Seafood is a must — clam chowder (always white, never red), lobster rolls, and oysters
Boston is a college city — it feels youngest and most energetic during the school year

health.overview: Boston has some of the best hospitals in the world. Massachusetts General Hospital, Brigham and Women's, and Beth Israel are world-renowned. Medical tourism is common. Standard US healthcare costs.
health.water: Tap water is safe and excellent.
health.altitude: No altitude concerns. Winters are cold and snowy. Nor'easters can disrupt travel — check forecasts in winter months.

faq.a: Very safe. Boston is one of the safest major US cities. Tourist areas are well-maintained and safe. Crime is concentrated in neighborhoods tourists don't visit.
Yes, the T is safe during operating hours. It closes around 12:30am, so plan for Uber/Lyft for late nights.

faq.q: Can I walk everywhere in Boston?
faq.a: Mostly yes. The Freedom Trail, Back Bay, North End, and waterfront are all walkable. The T fills gaps for longer distances like Cambridge.

faq.q: Do I need a car in Boston?
faq.a: No, and you shouldn't get one. Boston streets are confusing, parking is expensive, and the T and walking cover everything.

faq.q: When is the best time to visit Boston?
faq.a: September through November for fall foliage and comfortable weather. Spring is also lovely. Winter is cold and snowy but has holiday charm. Summer is warm and busy.

cities.name: Philadelphia
cities.summary: Philadelphia is a city of contrasts — world-class museums and restaurants alongside some genuinely rough neighborhoods. Center City, Old City, and Rittenhouse Square are safe and enjoyable. North Philadelphia and parts of West Philadelphia have high crime rates. The tourist areas are well-policed and rewarding to explore.
cities.quickVerdict: Center City and Old City are safe for tourists. The historic sites around Independence Hall are well-maintained and policed. Rittenhouse Square is the best neighborhood for dining and walking. SEPTA transit covers tourist areas well. Don't wander into North Philadelphia. Philly has amazing food and history at lower prices than NYC or DC.

neighborhoods.name: Center City / Rittenhouse
neighborhoods.description: Philadelphia's downtown. Rittenhouse Square is the city's best neighborhood — beautiful park, great restaurants. Safe and walkable day and night.

neighborhoods.name: Old City
neighborhoods.description: Independence Hall, Liberty Bell, and the historic district. Tourist-friendly and well-policed. Good restaurants and First Friday gallery events. Safe.

neighborhoods.name: Fishtown / Northern Liberties
neighborhoods.description: Trendy, gentrified neighborhoods with great food and nightlife. Safe on main streets. Some rougher edges on the borders. Frankford Avenue is the main strip.

neighborhoods.name: South Street / Passyunk
neighborhoods.description: South Street is eclectic and fun. East Passyunk Avenue has the city's best restaurant row. Safe during the day and evening.

neighborhoods.name: University City
neighborhoods.description: Penn and Drexel campuses. Safe around the universities. Borders rougher areas — stay near campus. Good restaurants and cultural venues.

neighborhoods.name: North Philadelphia / Kensington
neighborhoods.description: Kensington has one of the worst open-air drug markets in the US. North Philadelphia has high violent crime. No tourist attractions. Avoid entirely.

scams.name: Aggressive Panhandling
scams.description: Center City and Suburban Station have aggressive panhandlers. Some use sob stories about needing bus fare or food.
scams.howToAvoid: A brief 'sorry' and keep walking. Don't engage in extended conversations.

scams.name: Parking Hustles
scams.description: Unofficial parking attendants in South Philly and near stadiums claim to be managing parking for events.
scams.howToAvoid: Only pay at official lots or metered spots. Use the PPA parking app.

scams.name: SEPTA Fare Evasion Traps
scams.description: Not a scam against you, but SEPTA police do random fare checks. Make sure you have a valid pass.
scams.howToAvoid: Always tap your SEPTA Key or pay your fare. Fines are steep.

scams.name: Counterfeit Event Tickets
scams.description: Fake tickets sold outside stadiums and concert venues.
scams.howToAvoid: Buy tickets from official sources only.

soloFemale.overview: Philadelphia is reasonably comfortable for solo women in tourist areas. Center City and Rittenhouse are great. The city has a friendly, down-to-earth culture. More caution needed outside the tourist core.
tips: Rittenhouse Square area is the most comfortable base for solo women
Old City and Center City are safe for solo exploration during the day
SEPTA is fine during the day — use Uber/Lyft at night
East Passyunk has wonderful solo dining options
Reading Terminal Market is a great solo lunch spot
Avoid North Philadelphia and Kensington completely

nightSafety.overview: Rittenhouse, Old City, and Fishtown have the best nightlife and are safe on main streets. Center City empties out after business hours in some areas. SEPTA has limited late-night service.
tips: Rittenhouse and Old City are safe for evening dining and walks
Fishtown has great bars and is safe on Frankford Avenue
SEPTA's last trains run around midnight — plan for Uber after that
Avoid Broad Street north of City Hall at night
South Street gets lively on weekends and is safe on the main strip

transport.metro: SEPTA has subway, trolley, and bus lines covering the city. The Broad Street Line and Market-Frankford Line cover tourist areas. Use a SEPTA Key card. Generally safe during the day.
transport.rideshare: Uber and Lyft are widely available and recommended for nighttime travel.
transport.taxis: Less common than ride-hailing but available at hotels and Center City.
transport.tips: Center City is very walkable. SEPTA for longer distances. Philadelphia is between NYC and DC on Amtrak — easy day trip from either.

customs: Philadelphians are passionate and direct — it's called 'Philly attitude' and it's actually endearing once you get used to it
Tipping: 18-20%, standard US tipping. Tip well at the famous cheesesteak spots and they'll remember you
Cheesesteak ordering protocol: 'Whiz wit' means Cheez Whiz with onions. Know your order before reaching the window at Pat's or Geno's
BYOB restaurants are a Philly institution — many excellent restaurants don't have liquor licenses but let you bring wine
The art scene is underrated — the Philadelphia Museum of Art, Barnes Foundation, and street murals are world-class
Sports fans here are intense — don't wear rival team gear unless you want good-natured (or not) ribbing

health.overview: Philadelphia has excellent hospitals. Penn Medicine, Jefferson Health, and Temple University Hospital are major medical centers. Standard US healthcare costs.
health.water: Tap water is safe to drink.
health.altitude: No altitude concerns. Summers are hot and humid. Winters can be cold with occasional nor'easters.

faq.a: In the tourist areas, yes. Center City, Old City, Rittenhouse, and Fishtown are safe and enjoyable. Crime is higher in North Philadelphia and Kensington — areas tourists don't need to visit.
During the day, yes. Less comfortable late at night. Use Uber/Lyft after dark.
Significantly cheaper — hotels, restaurants, and attractions are all less expensive. Similar quality experiences at much better prices.

faq.q: What food should I try in Philadelphia?
faq.a: Cheesesteaks (try Pat's, Geno's, or Jim's), roast pork sandwiches at DiNic's, and anything at Reading Terminal Market. The BYOB restaurant scene is also excellent.

faq.q: Can I walk between Philadelphia's main attractions?
faq.a: Yes, most historic sites are clustered around Old City and Center City — very walkable. Rittenhouse is a short walk south. Fishtown requires transit or a short Uber.

cities.name: San Diego
cities.summary: San Diego is one of the safest large cities in the United States. Beautiful beaches, perfect weather, and a laid-back vibe make it ideal for tourists. The Gaslamp Quarter, La Jolla, and Coronado are all very safe. Property crime is lower than LA or SF. The only real downside is that you need a car for most things.
cities.quickVerdict: San Diego is very safe and one of the easiest US cities to visit. The beaches, Balboa Park, and Gaslamp Quarter are all safe and tourist-friendly. You'll likely need a car or Uber as the city is spread out. The biggest risk is sunburn, not crime.

neighborhoods.name: Gaslamp Quarter
neighborhoods.description: Downtown's restaurant and nightlife district. Victorian buildings, great dining, safe and lively. Safe to walk day and night.

neighborhoods.name: La Jolla
neighborhoods.description: Upscale coastal neighborhood. Beautiful coves, great restaurants, and the Birch Aquarium. One of the safest areas in San Diego.

neighborhoods.name: Coronado
neighborhoods.description: Island across the bay with the iconic Hotel del Coronado. Beautiful beach, extremely safe. Family-friendly. Worth a day trip.

neighborhoods.name: Pacific Beach / Mission Beach
neighborhoods.description: Beach party neighborhoods. Young, lively, safe during the day. Can get rowdy on weekend nights. Boardwalk is great for walking and biking.

neighborhoods.name: North Park / Hillcrest
neighborhoods.description: Trendy neighborhoods with craft breweries, restaurants, and the LGBTQ+ community. Safe and walkable on main streets.

neighborhoods.name: East Village / Downtown East
neighborhoods.description: Improving area near Petco Park but still has homeless population and some property crime. Fine during events, less comfortable otherwise.

scams.name: Beach Theft
scams.description: Belongings left on the beach while swimming are stolen. Common at all San Diego beaches.
scams.howToAvoid: Don't leave valuables unattended. Use a waterproof pouch for phone and keys. Take turns watching belongings.

scams.name: Tijuana Border Scams
scams.description: Walking across to Tijuana is popular but returns can involve long waits. Some scams target tourists on the Mexico side — overpriced taxis, fake police.
scams.howToAvoid: If visiting Tijuana, bring your passport, use the pedestrian crossing, and be aware that safety rules change once you cross. Consider an organized tour.

scams.name: Parking Enforcement
scams.description: Beach parking fills up fast and meters are strictly enforced. Tow-away zones can catch visitors.
scams.howToAvoid: Use paid parking lots or the ParkMobile app. Don't risk metered spots — the fines are steep.

scams.name: Overpriced Tours
scams.description: Some tour operators charge premium prices for things you can do cheaply on your own (whale watching, La Jolla seals).
scams.howToAvoid: You can see the La Jolla seals for free from the cliffs. Compare tour prices online before booking at the dock.

soloFemale.overview: San Diego is excellent for solo women — one of the safest US cities with a friendly, relaxed culture. The beach communities are particularly comfortable.
tips: San Diego is one of the safest US cities for solo women
La Jolla, Coronado, and the Gaslamp Quarter are all very comfortable
The beach culture is relaxed and welcoming to solo travelers
Balboa Park is a wonderful solo exploration area — museums, gardens, and the zoo
North Park and Hillcrest have great solo dining and café options
Uber/Lyft is necessary for getting between areas

nightSafety.overview: San Diego is safe at night in most tourist areas. The Gaslamp Quarter is the main nightlife district and is well-policed. Pacific Beach can get rowdy on weekends but is physically safe.
tips: The Gaslamp Quarter is safe and lively at night
Pacific Beach bars get rowdy on weekends but serious incidents are rare
La Jolla and Coronado are quiet and safe in the evening
Downtown east of the Gaslamp is less comfortable at night
The beach boardwalks are fine for evening walks in the summer

transport.metro: The Trolley covers downtown, Old Town, and reaches the border at San Ysidro. Limited coverage elsewhere. The bus system fills gaps but is slow. Both are safe.
transport.rideshare: Uber and Lyft are essential for getting around San Diego. The city is spread out and not walkable between areas.
transport.taxis: Available at the airport and hotels. Ride-hailing is more convenient.
transport.tips: Rent a car for maximum flexibility — San Diego is a driving city. Parking is easier than LA or SF. The Trolley works for downtown and Old Town.

customs: San Diego is laid-back — casual dress is fine everywhere except upscale restaurants
Tipping: 18-20%, standard US tipping
The craft beer scene is among the best in the US — brewery tours are a must
Fish tacos are the local specialty — roadside stands often have the best ones
San Diego is close to the Mexico border — Tijuana is an easy day trip
Sun protection is important year-round — San Diego gets 266 sunny days per year

health.overview: Excellent healthcare. Scripps Health and UC San Diego Health are top facilities. Standard US healthcare costs.
health.water: Tap water is safe to drink.
health.altitude: No altitude concerns. Perfect weather most of the year. The sun is strong — use sunscreen daily.

faq.a: Yes, San Diego is one of the safest large cities in the US. Tourist areas are clean, well-maintained, and safe. Property crime exists but is lower than LA or SF.

faq.q: Do I need a car in San Diego?
faq.a: For the full experience, yes. San Diego is spread out. You can manage with Uber/Lyft but a car makes beach-hopping and exploring much easier.

faq.q: Is it safe to walk across to Tijuana?
faq.a: The border crossing is safe. Tijuana itself requires more awareness — stick to the tourist zone (Avenida Revolución), don't wander, and bring your passport for re-entry.

faq.q: What's the weather like in San Diego?
faq.a: Near-perfect year-round. Average highs of 18-26°C (65-78°F). Rain is rare. The coast can have morning fog (June Gloom) in early summer.
Very safe during the day. The park is well-maintained with museums, gardens, and the San Diego Zoo. Stick to main paths if visiting at dusk.

cities.name: Seattle
cities.summary: Seattle is generally safe for tourists with some notable exceptions. The Pike Place Market area, Capitol Hill, and Fremont are all safe and vibrant. The city has visible homelessness issues, particularly around 3rd Avenue downtown and Pioneer Square. Beyond that, it's a beautiful, progressive city with great food, coffee, and nature access.
cities.quickVerdict: Seattle's tourist areas are safe. Pike Place Market, the Space Needle, and Capitol Hill are enjoyable and well-maintained. Parts of downtown around 3rd Avenue and Pioneer Square have visible drug use and homelessness. These areas aren't typically dangerous to tourists but are uncomfortable. Use light rail and Uber to get around.

neighborhoods.name: Pike Place / Waterfront
neighborhoods.description: The iconic market, original Starbucks, and waterfront attractions. Tourist central. Safe and lively during the day. Quieter at night but still comfortable.

neighborhoods.name: Capitol Hill
neighborhoods.description: Vibrant, diverse neighborhood. Best nightlife, restaurants, and bars. LGBTQ+ friendly. Safe on main streets. Some property crime.

neighborhoods.name: Fremont / Ballard
neighborhoods.description: Quirky Fremont (the 'Center of the Universe') and brewery-heavy Ballard. Safe, fun, and less touristy. Great farmers markets.

neighborhoods.name: Queen Anne
neighborhoods.description: Space Needle and Seattle Center are here. Upper Queen Anne is residential and safe. Lower Queen Anne has restaurants and is comfortable.

neighborhoods.name: Pioneer Square
neighborhoods.description: Historic neighborhood with beautiful architecture. Underground Tour is here. But also has the city's most visible homelessness and drug activity. Fine during business hours, less comfortable at night.

neighborhoods.name: 3rd Avenue Downtown
neighborhoods.description: The stretch of 3rd Avenue south of Pike Street is the most problematic area in Seattle. Open drug use and dealing. Not dangerous but very uncomfortable. Walk one block east or west to avoid it.

scams.name: Pike Place Market Overcharging
scams.description: Some market vendors charge tourist premiums for produce, flowers, and seafood.
scams.howToAvoid: Compare prices between stalls. The fish-throwing show is free to watch. Quality is generally high throughout the market.

scams.name: Parking Enforcement
scams.description: Seattle parking enforcement is aggressive. Meters, zone restrictions, and steep fines.
scams.howToAvoid: Use the PayByPhone app for meters. Better yet, take light rail or Uber and skip the car in the city.

scams.name: Tech Bro Startup Pitches
scams.description: Not really a scam, but in Seattle you may encounter people pitching startup ideas or crypto schemes in coffee shops and co-working spaces.
scams.howToAvoid: Politely decline. Seattle's tech culture is genuine but some opportunists target visitors.

scams.name: Fake Homeless Stories
scams.description: Elaborate stories requesting specific amounts of money for bus tickets, prescriptions, etc.
scams.howToAvoid: Give to established charities if you want to help. A polite 'sorry' and keep walking.

soloFemale.overview: Seattle is very comfortable for solo women. The progressive culture means a welcoming, respectful atmosphere. Capitol Hill, Fremont, and Ballard are all great for solo exploration.
tips: Seattle is one of the most comfortable US cities for solo women
Capitol Hill and Fremont/Ballard are excellent neighborhoods for solo exploration
The coffee shop culture is perfect for solo travelers — Seattle invented it
Pike Place Market is a wonderful solo experience during the day
The Link Light Rail is safe and connects the airport to downtown and Capitol Hill
Day trips to Bainbridge Island (by ferry) are easy and safe solo activities

nightSafety.overview: Capitol Hill is the main nightlife area and is safe on busy streets. Ballard has a brewery scene that's safe and fun. Downtown south of Pike Street and Pioneer Square are less comfortable after dark.
tips: Capitol Hill's Broadway and Pike/Pine corridor are safe and lively at night
Ballard's brewery district is safe and fun in the evening
Avoid Pioneer Square and 3rd Avenue downtown after dark
The waterfront is pleasant for evening walks in summer
Use Uber/Lyft or light rail for late-night transport

transport.metro: Link Light Rail connects the airport to downtown, Capitol Hill, and the University of Washington. Clean, safe, and reliable. Buses cover the rest of the city well.
transport.rideshare: Uber and Lyft are widely available. Good option for areas not covered by light rail.
transport.taxis: Less common than ride-hailing. Available at the airport and downtown hotels.
transport.tips: Light rail from the airport is the best way into the city. Downtown is walkable. Uber for Capitol Hill to Ballard/Fremont. The ferry to Bainbridge Island is a must-do experience.

customs: Seattle is progressive and environmentally conscious — recycling and composting are taken seriously
Coffee culture is a way of life — don't order a Starbucks when there's an independent roaster on every corner
Tipping: 18-20%, standard US tipping
The 'Seattle Freeze' is real — locals can seem friendly on the surface but hard to befriend deeply. Don't take it personally
Rain is frequent but rarely heavy — a light rain jacket is better than an umbrella (locals don't use umbrellas)
Outdoor culture is huge — hiking, kayaking, and skiing are all within easy reach

health.overview: Seattle has excellent hospitals. Virginia Mason, Swedish Medical Center, and UW Medical Center are top facilities. Standard US healthcare costs.
health.water: Tap water is safe and excellent — sourced from mountain reservoirs.
health.altitude: No altitude concerns. Rain is frequent but usually light. Bring layers and waterproof gear.

faq.a: Yes, Seattle's tourist areas are safe. Pike Place Market, Capitol Hill, and the Space Needle area are well-maintained. Downtown around 3rd Avenue has visible homelessness but isn't typically dangerous.

faq.q: Does it really rain all the time in Seattle?
faq.a: It rains frequently but lightly. Seattle actually gets less total rainfall than NYC or Miami. It's more constant drizzle than heavy downpours. A rain jacket is all you need.
Yes, Capitol Hill is safe and one of the best neighborhoods to explore. It has the best food, nightlife, and culture in the city. Standard big-city precautions apply.

faq.q: Do I need a car in Seattle?
faq.a: Not for the city itself. Light rail, buses, and Uber cover tourist areas. Rent a car only if you're doing day trips to Mount Rainier, Olympic National Park, or San Juan Islands.

faq.q: Is Pike Place Market worth visiting?
faq.a: Absolutely — it's one of the best public markets in the US. Go in the morning for the best experience. The first Starbucks is here but the independent coffee shops are better.

cities.name: Denver
cities.summary: Denver is a safe, active city that serves as a gateway to the Rocky Mountains. LoDo, RiNo, and Cherry Creek are all safe and vibrant neighborhoods. The city has some issues with property crime and visible homelessness along the 16th Street Mall, but tourist areas are well-maintained. Altitude is a real factor — Denver sits at 5,280 feet.
cities.quickVerdict: Denver is safe for tourists in the main neighborhoods. LoDo, RiNo, and Capitol Hill have great dining and nightlife. The 16th Street Mall has some homelessness issues but is safe for walking. Take the altitude seriously — drink water, go easy on alcohol the first day. The mountains are easily accessible for day trips.

neighborhoods.name: LoDo (Lower Downtown)
neighborhoods.description: Historic district with Union Station, Coors Field, and great restaurants. Safe and lively. The best starting point for visitors.

neighborhoods.name: RiNo (River North Art District)
neighborhoods.description: Denver's trendiest neighborhood. Craft breweries, street art, and food halls. Safe during the day and evening. Some rougher edges at the borders.

neighborhoods.name: Cherry Creek
neighborhoods.description: Upscale shopping and dining. Very safe. More residential feel with excellent restaurants.

neighborhoods.name: Capitol Hill
neighborhoods.description: Denver's most eclectic neighborhood. Great bars, restaurants, and nightlife. Safe on main streets. Some property crime.

neighborhoods.name: 16th Street Mall
neighborhoods.description: Pedestrian mall through downtown. Good restaurants at each end but the middle stretch has aggressive panhandlers and visible homelessness. Safe but uncomfortable in stretches.

neighborhoods.name: East Colfax
neighborhoods.description: Stretches of East Colfax Avenue east of Capitol Hill have drug activity and higher crime. Some gentrification but still rough in places.

scams.name: Altitude-related Overindulgence
scams.description: Not a scam, but the #1 tourist mistake. Alcohol hits harder at altitude. Cannabis edibles hit harder at altitude. Combined with dehydration, this sends people to the ER.
scams.howToAvoid: Drink twice the water you normally would. Go easy on alcohol the first two days. If trying cannabis, start with a very low dose (2.5-5mg) and wait 2 hours before more.

scams.name: Cannabis Dispensary Upselling
scams.description: Some dispensaries push tourists toward expensive products. Staff earn commissions on certain items.
scams.howToAvoid: Research strains and products before visiting. Set a budget. Ask for recommendations based on experience level — good budtenders will be honest.

scams.name: Ski Trip Overcharging
scams.description: Tour operators charge premium prices for transportation to ski resorts that are easy to reach independently.
scams.howToAvoid: Rent a car or use the Bustang/Snowstang bus to ski resorts. Much cheaper than organized tours.

scams.name: 16th Street Mall Hustlers
scams.description: Standard big-city panhandling and hustling on the pedestrian mall.
scams.howToAvoid: Politely decline and keep walking. Not threatening, just persistent.

soloFemale.overview: Denver is comfortable for solo women. The city has an active, outdoorsy culture that's welcoming. LoDo and RiNo are great neighborhoods for solo exploration. The craft brewery scene is social and friendly.
tips: LoDo, RiNo, and Cherry Creek are the most comfortable areas for solo women
Denver's brewery culture is very social and welcoming to solo visitors
The outdoor activity scene (hiking, biking) makes it easy to join group activities
Capitol Hill has great nightlife that's comfortable for solo women
Denver is relatively compact and easy to navigate
Take altitude seriously — it affects everything from energy to alcohol tolerance

nightSafety.overview: LoDo, RiNo, and Capitol Hill have good nightlife and are safe on main streets. The 16th Street Mall is less comfortable after dark. Denver's nightlife is earlier than NYC or LA — most things wrap up by 1-2am.
tips: LoDo around Union Station is the safest evening area
RiNo has great bars and is safe on the main strips
Capitol Hill's Colfax Avenue has dive bars and late-night spots — safe but gritty
Avoid the middle stretch of 16th Street Mall after dark
Uber is recommended after midnight

transport.metro: RTD light rail connects the airport to Union Station (37 minutes, $10.50). Local buses and light rail cover the city. The free 16th Street Mall shuttle runs the length of downtown.
transport.rideshare: Uber and Lyft are widely available. Essential for RiNo and Capitol Hill at night.
transport.taxis: Less common than ride-hailing. Available at the airport and downtown hotels.
transport.tips: Light rail from DEN airport is the best way into the city. Downtown is walkable. Rent a car for mountain day trips — I-70 to the ski resorts is the main route.

customs: Denver is the Mile High City — altitude is real and affects everyone differently. Hydrate aggressively
Cannabis is legal and dispensaries are everywhere. Consumption is not allowed in public — edibles in your hotel room are the easiest option
Tipping: 18-20%, standard US tipping. Tip budtenders at dispensaries ($1-5)
Outdoor culture is huge — locals hike, ski, bike, and climb year-round
Craft beer is a religion — Denver has over 100 breweries. A brewery tour is practically required
The weather can change rapidly — dress in layers and bring sunscreen even in winter (the sun is intense at altitude)

health.overview: Denver Health, UCHealth, and SCL Health have excellent facilities. Standard US healthcare costs. Altitude sickness is a real concern for visitors from sea level.
health.water: Tap water is safe and tastes good — sourced from mountain snowmelt.
health.altitude: Denver is at 1,609m (5,280ft). Altitude affects hydration, alcohol tolerance, and energy levels. Drink extra water. Most people adjust within 1-2 days. If heading to the mountains (3,000m+), take it even more seriously.

faq.a: Yes, Denver's main neighborhoods are safe. LoDo, RiNo, Cherry Creek, and Capitol Hill are all enjoyable. The 16th Street Mall has some homelessness issues but isn't dangerous.

faq.q: Will I get altitude sickness in Denver?
faq.a: Possibly mild symptoms — headache, fatigue, shortness of breath. Drink lots of water, avoid heavy alcohol the first day, and take it easy. Most people adjust within 24-48 hours.
Yes, recreational cannabis is legal for adults 21+. Purchase from licensed dispensaries only. Public consumption is illegal — use in private spaces. Start with very low doses, especially at altitude.

faq.q: Do I need a car in Denver?
faq.a: For the city itself, not necessarily — light rail, buses, and Uber work well. For mountain day trips, you'll want a car.

faq.q: How close are the ski resorts?
faq.a: The nearest major resorts (Loveland, Arapahoe Basin) are about 90 minutes. Vail and Breckenridge are 2 hours. I-70 traffic on weekends can be brutal — leave early.

cities.name: Nashville
cities.summary: Nashville is a booming tourist destination with a generally safe downtown core. Broadway (the main honky-tonk strip) is heavily policed and lively. The city has grown rapidly and most tourist areas are well-maintained. Some property crime exists, and the pedal tavern / party bus culture means weekend nights can be chaotic. Great music, food, and Southern hospitality.
cities.quickVerdict: Nashville's tourist areas are safe. Broadway and the Gulch are the main draws and are well-policed. The bachelorette party capital of America gets rowdy on weekends but it's fun-rowdy, not dangerous-rowdy. Use Uber (the city has limited public transit). The live music scene is genuinely world-class.

neighborhoods.name: Broadway / Downtown
neighborhoods.description: The honky-tonk strip. Loud, fun, and safe due to heavy police and security presence. Gets very crowded on weekends. Stick to main streets.

neighborhoods.name: The Gulch
neighborhoods.description: Trendy neighborhood with restaurants, bars, and the famous Nashville sign mural. Very safe and walkable. Good hotel area.

neighborhoods.name: East Nashville
neighborhoods.description: Hip, eclectic neighborhood with great food and local music venues. Safe on main streets. More authentic than Broadway.

neighborhoods.name: 12 South
neighborhoods.description: Charming neighborhood with boutiques, coffee shops, and the 'I Believe in Nashville' mural. Very safe. Great for daytime exploration.

neighborhoods.name: Germantown
neighborhoods.description: Historic neighborhood north of downtown. Excellent restaurants. Safe and walkable. Near the farmers market.

neighborhoods.name: North Nashville
neighborhoods.description: Higher crime rates. Some areas are gentrifying but others remain rough. Not a tourist destination. Stick to Germantown if exploring north of downtown.

scams.name: Broadway Cover Charges
scams.description: Some bars on Broadway charge cover fees on busy nights that they don't advertise. Others have minimum drink purchases.
scams.howToAvoid: Most Broadway honky-tonks don't charge cover (that's their selling point). If one does, just go next door.

scams.name: Pedal Tavern / Party Bus Upselling
scams.description: Party vehicles quote low prices then add fees for route changes, time extensions, and mandatory tips.
scams.howToAvoid: Read the full terms before booking. Confirm all costs upfront. Book through established companies.

scams.name: Hot Chicken Heat Levels
scams.description: Nashville hot chicken is genuinely extremely spicy. 'Medium' at a local spot can be far hotter than you expect.
scams.howToAvoid: Start with 'mild' your first time, even if you think you can handle heat. You can always go hotter next time.

scams.name: Overpriced Parking Downtown
scams.description: Downtown parking lots charge $30-50+ on busy nights. Some lots raise prices as events approach.
scams.howToAvoid: Park further out and Uber in, or use the SpotHero app to find reasonable rates. Some hotels include parking.

soloFemale.overview: Nashville is popular with solo women and bachelorette groups. Broadway is safe due to the crowds and police presence. The culture is friendly and approachable. The main concern is the party atmosphere — watch your drinks.
tips: Nashville is welcoming to solo women — Southern hospitality is real
Broadway and the Gulch are safe and easy to navigate
Watch your drinks on Broadway — the party atmosphere can provide cover for spiking
East Nashville and 12 South are great for solo daytime exploration
Uber is essential — Nashville has minimal public transit
The live music scene makes solo nights out enjoyable — sit at the bar and enjoy the show

nightSafety.overview: Broadway is the main nightlife area and is safe due to crowds and police. It's loud and chaotic on weekends but physically safe. The Gulch is a more relaxed alternative. Limited options for late-night transit.
tips: Broadway is safe at night — heavy police presence keeps serious crime at bay
The Gulch has a more upscale, calmer evening scene
East Nashville has local music venues that are less chaotic than Broadway
Use Uber/Lyft for all nighttime transport
Avoid walking far from Broadway into unfamiliar areas at night

transport.metro: Nashville has very limited public transit. WeGo buses exist but are slow and infrequent. This is a car/ride-hailing city.
transport.rideshare: Uber and Lyft are essential in Nashville. This is your primary transport option. Surge pricing on weekend nights downtown.
transport.taxis: Available but ride-hailing is more convenient.
transport.tips: Uber for everything. Downtown is walkable between Broadway, the Gulch, and Germantown. A rental car is helpful for day trips but not needed for downtown.

customs: Southern hospitality is genuine — people are friendly, polite, and chatty. Embrace it
Tipping: 18-20%, and tip generously to musicians. They play for tips on Broadway
Nashville hot chicken is a must-try but start mild — it's not a joke level of spice
Live music is everywhere and mostly free on Broadway — walk in, enjoy, and tip the band
Bachelorette parties are a huge part of Broadway culture on weekends — expect pedal taverns and matching outfits
Country music is the headline, but Nashville also has incredible rock, blues, and Americana scenes

health.overview: Vanderbilt University Medical Center is world-class. Multiple other excellent facilities. Standard US healthcare costs.
health.water: Tap water is safe to drink.
health.altitude: No altitude concerns. Summers are hot and humid. Tornado season (spring) is real — check weather alerts.

faq.a: Yes, Nashville's tourist areas are safe. Broadway is heavily policed. The Gulch, East Nashville, and 12 South are all comfortable to explore.
Yes, Broadway is safe at night due to police and security presence. It's loud and chaotic on weekends (especially with bachelorette parties) but physically safe.

faq.q: Do I need a car in Nashville?
faq.a: For just Broadway and downtown, no — Uber covers it. For day trips to the countryside or specific neighborhoods, a car is helpful.

faq.q: Is the music really free on Broadway?
faq.a: Yes, most honky-tonks have free live music all day and night. No cover charge. You're expected to buy drinks and tip the musicians.

faq.q: How spicy is Nashville hot chicken really?
faq.a: Very. 'Medium' at places like Prince's or Hattie B's is genuinely painful for most people. Start with mild. The flavor is incredible at any heat level.

cities.name: Austin
cities.summary: Austin is one of the safer large cities in Texas. The city has a young, progressive vibe and a legendary live music scene. 6th Street is the main nightlife strip and is heavily policed. South Congress and East Austin are safe and trendy. Like most Texas cities, it's car-dependent, and the heat in summer is intense.
cities.quickVerdict: Austin is safe for tourists. 6th Street (Dirty Sixth) is rowdy but safe on the main strip. Rainey Street and South Congress are more relaxed alternatives. The music scene is genuine and accessible. You'll need a car or Uber — Austin's public transit is limited. Watch for heat in summer — 40°C (104°F) is normal.

neighborhoods.name: South Congress (SoCo)
neighborhoods.description: Iconic Austin strip with food trucks, boutiques, and the 'I love you so much' mural. Safe, walkable, and very Austin. Great during the day.

neighborhoods.name: Downtown / 6th Street
neighborhoods.description: 'Dirty Sixth' is the main bar strip — rowdy and chaotic on weekends but heavily policed. West 6th and Rainey Street are more upscale alternatives. Safe on the main strips.

neighborhoods.name: East Austin
neighborhoods.description: The city's trendiest area. Food trucks, craft cocktails, and street art. Safe on the main streets. Rapidly gentrifying.

neighborhoods.name: Zilker / Barton Springs
neighborhoods.description: Beautiful park area, Barton Springs Pool, and the trailhead for the greenbelt. Very safe. Family-friendly. ACL Festival is held here.

neighborhoods.name: The Domain
neighborhoods.description: Outdoor shopping and dining complex in North Austin. Very safe. Feels suburban but has good restaurants and hotels.

neighborhoods.name: Rundberg / North Lamar
neighborhoods.description: Higher property crime rates. Not a tourist area. Some good international restaurants but otherwise no reason to visit.

scams.name: 6th Street Drink Prices
scams.description: Bars on Dirty Sixth may not clearly display prices. Drinks can be surprisingly expensive during events like SXSW or ACL.
scams.howToAvoid: Ask prices before ordering. Rainey Street and East Austin generally have better value.

scams.name: Festival Ticket Scalping
scams.description: During SXSW, ACL, and other festivals, scalpers sell counterfeit or overpriced tickets and wristbands.
scams.howToAvoid: Buy tickets only from official festival websites. Wristbands that have been tampered with won't scan.

scams.name: Food Truck Cash Only
scams.description: Some food trucks are cash-only and don't always post this clearly. ATM fees nearby can be steep.
scams.howToAvoid: Carry some cash. Most food trucks now take cards but not all.

scams.name: Heat Exhaustion
scams.description: Not a scam but a real danger from May through September. Visitors underestimate the Texas heat.
scams.howToAvoid: Hydrate constantly. Seek shade during midday. Plan outdoor activities for early morning or evening. The heat is no joke.

soloFemale.overview: Austin is very comfortable for solo women. The city has a progressive, welcoming culture. South Congress, East Austin, and the Domain are all easy to explore alone. The music scene makes solo nights out enjoyable.
tips: Austin is one of the most comfortable Texas cities for solo women
South Congress and East Austin are great for solo exploration
6th Street is fine for solo women but go to West 6th or Rainey Street for a more comfortable vibe
Live music venues are welcoming to solo audience members — sit at the bar and enjoy
Uber is essential — Austin's public transit is limited
The outdoor scene (hiking, swimming at Barton Springs) is very social and easy to do solo

nightSafety.overview: 6th Street is heavily policed on weekends and safe despite the chaos. Rainey Street is a more relaxed alternative. East Austin has great bars with a local feel. Limited late-night transit options.
tips: 6th Street is safe on the main strip — heavy police presence on weekends
Rainey Street is a more comfortable nightlife option — converted houses turned into bars
East Austin bars are less chaotic than 6th Street
Uber/Lyft for all nighttime transport
Avoid wandering off the main entertainment strips at night

transport.rideshare: Uber and Lyft are essential in Austin. The city is spread out and public transit doesn't cut it.

Houston is also in Hurricane Alley and floods frequently.
